segments.en: Linked Discourses 42
1. Chiefs
1. Vicious
At Sāvatthī.

segments.pli: Atha kho caṇḍo gāmaṇi yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho caṇḍo gāmaṇi bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then the chief named Fury went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

segments.pli: “ko nu kho, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo yena midhekacco caṇḍo caṇḍotveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
segments.en: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some people are regarded as furious,

segments.pli: Ko pana, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo yena midhekacco sorato soratotveva saṅkhaṃ gacchatī”ti?
segments.en: while others are regarded as sweet-natured?”
“Take someone who hasn’t given up greed.

segments.pli: Rāgassa appahīnattā pare kopenti, parehi kopiyamāno kopaṃ pātukaroti.
segments.en: So they get annoyed by others, and they show it.
They’re regarded as furious.
They haven’t given up hate.

segments.pli: Dosassa appahīnattā pare kopenti, parehi kopiyamāno kopaṃ pātukaroti.
segments.en: So they get annoyed by others, and they show it.
They’re regarded as furious.
They haven’t given up delusion.

segments.pli: Mohassa appahīnattā pare kopenti, parehi kopiyamāno kopaṃ pātukaroti.
segments.en: So they get annoyed by others, and they show it.
They’re regarded as furious.

segments.pli: Ayaṃ kho, gāmaṇi, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo yena midhekacco caṇḍo caṇḍotveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
segments.en: This is the cause, this is the reason why some people are regarded as furious.

segments.pli: Idha pana, gāmaṇi, ekaccassa rāgo pahīno hoti.
segments.en: But take someone who has given up greed.

segments.pli: Rāgassa pahīnattā pare na kopenti, parehi kopiyamāno kopaṃ na pātukaroti.
segments.en: So they don’t get annoyed by others, and don’t show it.
They’re regarded as sweet-natured.
They’ve given up hate.

segments.pli: Dosassa pahīnattā pare na kopenti, parehi kopiyamāno kopaṃ na pātukaroti.
segments.en: So they don’t get annoyed by others, and don’t show it.
They’re regarded as sweet-natured.
They’ve given up delusion.

segments.pli: Mohassa pahīnattā pare na kopenti, parehi kopiyamāno kopaṃ na pātukaroti.
segments.en: So they don’t get annoyed by others, and don’t show it.
They’re regarded as sweet-natured.

segments.pli: Ayaṃ kho, gāmaṇi, hetu ayaṃ paccayo yena midhekacco sorato soratotveva saṅkhaṃ gacchatī”ti.
segments.en: This is the cause, this is the reason why some people are regarded as sweet-natured.”

segments.pli: Evaṃ vutte, caṇḍo gāmaṇi bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: When he said this, the chief named Fury said to the Buddha,
“Excellent, sir! Excellent!

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṃ bhagavatā anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
segments.en: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with good eyes can see what’s there, the Buddha has made the teaching clear in many ways.

segments.pli: Esāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
segments.en: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

segments.pli: Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
segments.en: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

suttaplex.blurb: A headman known for his aggressive nature approaches the Buddha and asks how to give up irritability. The Buddha points out that such reactions are fueled by greed, hate, and delusion.
